content:
You should definitely visit the Meiji Shrine when you get a chance! It's a serene oasis in the midst of bustling Harajuku.

The Kawai Shrine (), on the other hand, is a smaller, lesser-known shrine located in a quiet alleyway in Harajuku. It's not as famous as the Meiji Shrine, but it has its own unique charm and history.

The Kawai Shrine is dedicated to the god of agriculture, fertility, and industry. It's said to bring good luck and prosperity to those who visit. The shrine is particularly famous for its beautiful gardens, which are especially stunning during the cherry blossom season (March-April) and the autumn foliage season (November-December).

One of the unique features of the Kawai Shrine is its "Lucky Bell." According to legend, if you ring the bell and make a wish, it will come true. Many visitors come to the shrine to ring the bell and pray for good fortune.

The shrine also has a small souvenir shop selling traditional Japanese goods, such as omamori (lucky charms) and ema (wooden prayer tablets). You can write your wishes on the ema and hang them at the shrine, which is a lovely way to participate in the local culture.

The Kawai Shrine is a hidden gem in Harajuku, and it's a great place to escape the crowds and chaos of the main streets. If you're interested in exploring more of Harajuku's historical side, I'd definitely recommend adding it to your list!

Now, back to your Yokohama trip... Are you planning to try any of the local specialties, such as Yokohama-style ramen or Chinatown's delicious street food?
